cornish:
Lev Yowann Parker rekordyes
gans Mick Paynter yn Lannanta 4ves Mis Ebril 2008
english: The Voice of Yowann Parker recorded by Mick Paynter in Lelant 4th April 2008

cornish: Myttin da, a Yowann.
english: Good Morning,Yowann.

cornish: Myttin da.
english: Good Morning.

cornish: Fatla genes. Os ta yn poynt da ?
english: How are you, are you in good shape ?

cornish: Yn poynt da meur ras.
english: In good shape thankyou.

cornish: Wel yma nebes govynnadow omma.
english: Well, there are some questions here.

cornish: Pur dha.
english: Very good.

cornish: Y'n kynsa le, prag y hwruss' ta dyski Kernewek?
english: In the first place why did you learn Cornish ?

cornish: Pan...pan en vy ow triga yn kynsa yn Kernow my a wodhya... my a wodhya bos yeth Kernewek  kewsys ha skrifys y'n konteth,yn trev, ha pan wrav vy mos adro dhe vro, mos..da yw genev dyski an  yeth, ytho my a wra ..wrug dalleth dhe dhyski Kernewek.
english: When... when I was first living in Cornwall I knew, I was aware that the Cornish language was written and spoken in  the county, at home , and when I went about a country I like to learn the language, so I started to learn Cornish.

cornish: Mes .... nyns os Kernow dha honan ?
english: But ....you're not a Cornishman yourself ?

cornish: Na,na, nyns ov vy Kernow.Na na Sowson ov vy, mes ..ah..pan en vy yowynk my eth dhe Gembra,  ha dyski nebes Kembrek ha pur dhe les o, ha nyns o Kembrek ma dihaval dhe Kernewek, ytho, res o  dhym dyski an yeth awos y vos pur dhe les
english: No, no, I'm not Cornish, I'm English but ..ah. when I was young I went to Wales, and learnt some Welsh and very  interesting it was, and Welsh wasn't so unlike Cornish, so I had to learn the language because it was so very  interesting.

cornish: Wel delgrysav yma, yma ..eh.. peswar ugans kansrann a'n yeth, an erva Kernewek yw an keth  ages Kembrek...
english: Well, as I believe 80% of the language, the Cornish vocabulary is the same as the Welsh..

cornish: O ..Ya?
english: O ..Yeah?

cornish: Fatel wre' ta gul devnydh a dha Gernewek pub dydh oll ?
english: How do you use you Cornish every single day ?

cornish: A.... Boghes Kernewek... boghes lowr.. mes ny wrav vy kewsel Kernewek pubtydh mes my a wra  darbari dyskansow rag ow klas yn Kernewek. Klas gorthugher.... a ..ha'ga skrifa alena martesen po  redya martesen.
english: A.... a little Cornish...little enough..but I don't speak Cornish everyday but I prepare lessons for my class in Cornish.  An Evening class ,a.. and writing from thence maybe and perhaps reading.

cornish: Wel, pyth a wredh dha redya ?
english: Well, what do you read ?

cornish: Wel, my a wra redya An Gannas po an tekstow rag ow klas. My a wra studhya Resurrectio  Domini y'n eur ma gans peswara gradh.
english: Well, I read An Gannas or the texts for my class. I'm studying Resurrectio Domini at the moment with the fourth  grade.

cornish: Pyth a brederydh yn kever an tekstow koth ?
english: What do you think about the old texts ?

cornish: Pur splann yw...ens i...pur splann. Pur dhe les.
english: Quite splendid..they are ...quite splendid. V ery interesting.

cornish: Pur dhe les...
english: Very interesting..

cornish: Ha dhe wir yma nebes, nebes lavarow ynna ha na wrav vy ..emm..metya gensa yn Kernewek  kewsys po skrifys y'n eur ma. Martesen res yw dhynni dehweles dhe'n tekstow koth rag  dyski..emm..Kernewek ewn.
english: And it's true there are some phrase in in them which I 've not , emm, met in the written or spoken Cornish at this  time. Perhaps we should return to the old texts to teach correct Cornish.

cornish: Ya....hag..eus jynn amontya dhis ?
english: Yeah....and have you got a computer ?

cornish: ....lies Kernewek y'n jynn amontya..
english: ....much Cornish in the Computer..

cornish: Henn yw gwirionedh..yma lies gwiasvaow..
english: That's right there are many websites..

cornish: Ya ..ya...
english: Yes ..yes...

cornish: Ha lies tekst...
english: And many texts...

cornish: Oll an tekstow koth yw war ow jynn amontya, ha darbarys gans Keith Said, yma oll an teksts..Hag  an bibel..yn tien..wel rann an bibel.
english: All the old texts are on my computer, and prepared by Keith Said, there are all the texts..And the Bible.. complete  .. well part of the bible.

cornish: Rann an Bibel..
english: Part of the Bible..

cornish: Wel oll an Testament Nowydh treylyes dhe Gernewek gans Keith Said hag erell.
english: Well, all the New Testament translated into Cornish by Keith Said and others.

cornish: Hag yma war dowl dhe dreylya ynwedh an Testament Koth ?
english: And is it planned to translate the Old Testament too ?

cornish: Wel yma lies lyvrow.. my a wrug treylya lyvrow Ruth ha lyver Ecclesiastes, my ow honan, wel  gans Keith Said a wrug an brassa rann an ober.
english: Well there are many books, I translated the books Ruth and the book Ecclesiastes, myself, well with Keith Said who  did most of the work

cornish: Hag ynwe... an lyver an Apocrypha ?
english: And as we... the book of the Apocrypha ?

cornish: An Apocrypha, yma...wel ..yma Ecclesiasticus treylyes yn rann gans Jowann Richards, a wrug  merwel warlyna
english: A The Apocrypha, there is ..there is Ecclesiasticus part translated by Jowann Richards, who died last year

cornish: Ya
english: Yes

cornish: Mes ny wonn vy yn kever....... an lyvrow erell ..po na parth ena
english: But I don't know about...... the other books .. or any part of them.

cornish: An lyvrow erell ...
english: The other books ...

cornish: yma war'n jynn amontya oll an notennow skrifys gans Ray Edwards.
english: The notes written by Ray Edwards are all on the computer.

cornish: Ya pur dhe les an notennow.
english: Yes the notes are very interesting.

cornish: Pur dhe les, mes ytho..
english: Very interesting, so..

cornish: Ha ty....ty a wra dhegemmeres ha skrifa e-bostow ?
english: And you, you'll receive and write e-mails ?

cornish: Yn hwir..
english: Truly.

cornish: lytherow ?
english: Letters?

cornish: Lytherow .Ya....My a wrug skrifa lyther dhe Ray Edwards ow kodhvos gras dhodho rag oll y ober  yn Kernewek, ober splann yn Kernewek.
english: Truly. I did write a letter to Ray Edwards thanking him for all his work in Cornish, brilliant work in Cornish.

cornish: Pur splann .Wel nebes klav, ev yw, del grysav...
english: Very brilliant, he's somewhat ill now as I believe....

cornish: Ha gwann y dhewlagas ,yn y dhewlagas.
english: And his eyes are weak.. in his eyes.

cornish: Ya, mes .. bryntin y ober ev.
english: Yes, but .. his work is brilliant.

cornish: O ass yw henna... My a wrug, my wrug redya y Alis yn Vro an Varthusyon nans yw lies blydhen ha  hemm yw splann. Yma lies lavarow ynno, rag how you getting on ? Fatell wreta spedya ?
english: O how that is... I did, did read his Alice in Wonderland several years ago and that was splendid. There are many  phrases in it. How you getting on ? Fatell wreta spedya ?

cornish: Pur dha, pur dha. OK. Wel. Pyth esos ow kul hedhyw a-barth an yeth ni?
english: Very good, very good. OK. Well. What are you doing for our language today ?

cornish: Wel, my a wrug y dhyski, hi dyski y'n klas gorthugher, hag yma lies....nebes studhyoryon dhym....
english: Well, I do teach it, teach it in the evening class, and I've many students....

cornish: Py lies ?
english: How many ?

cornish: Wel y'n eur ma yma tri mes yma peswar orth omdenna yn eur ma mes delwaytyav i wra dehweles  dhe'n klas y'n blydhen a dheu, Tri yw studhyoryon rag ombrofya rag an peswara gradh .Hemm yw  ober pur gales. Mes i a wra , i a wra batalya.yn nevra.
english: Well, right now there are three but there are four retiring now but I expect them to return to the class next year.  Three are students who will take the fourth grade. That is very hard work. But they will , they will battle on for ever.

cornish: Wel del wodhyn ni yw ober pur pur gales, nyns yw saw an yeth, po saw an tekstow,yma istori,  literary criticism...
english: Well, as we know ourselves it's very, very hard work, it's not only language, or only the texts , there's history,  literary criticism...

cornish: Ha my a wra dasskrifa nebes.. my a wra ombrofya yn kesstriv lyennek, hevlyna war'n, war'n, war'n  Orsedh, henn yw yn yeth plen hwedhel adro dhe doll yn fordh.
english: And I'll write something out again, I'll enter into the literary competition, this year, for the, for the Gorsedd that's a  story in prose about a hole in the road.

cornish: Toll y'n fordh ? Ha ty yw bardh an Orsedh ynwedh ? Pyth yn dha brys sy yw poes an Orsedh  rag an Gonisogeth Kernow ?
english: A hole in the road ? And you're a Bard of the Gorsedd as well ? What in your mind is the importance of the  Gorsedd for the Cornish Culture ?

cornish: Ny wonn vy konvedhes ena, arta mar pleg .
english: I don't understand that, again please.

cornish: Pyth yw poes an Orsedh rag agan gonisegeth ni ?
english: What's the importance of the Gorsedd to our culture ?

cornish: Wel poes,dre yth yw,
english: Well, important, through, it is.

cornish: Pyth a wruss' ta yn dasserghyans Kernewek?
english: What did you do in the Cornish Revival ?

cornish: A boghes lowr , ny wrugav vy gul, ny wrug vy gul meur, marnas dyski an yeth, skrifa nebes lyvrow  ynno, po, my a wrug skrifa keskowsow , keskowsow...
english: Ah little enough , I didn't do, I didn't do much, except teach the language, write some books in it, or I wrote  conversations, conversations......

cornish: Keskowsow .
english: Conversations

cornish: Keskowsow rag an dhallethoryon.
english: Conversations for the beginners.

cornish: Avel gwariow..
english: As games.

cornish: Avel gwariow, keskowsow...
english: As games , conversations...

cornish: Didhanus ?
english: Amusing ?

cornish: Didhanus,Mar mynnta mes ..hag poes a kesstrivans y'n Orsedh , hag an lennans yn Truru pub  blydhen yn Kernewek, yn kesstriv hag yn.
english: Amusing if you like.. and important Gorsedd competitions, and the reading in Truro each year, in competition and  and in...

cornish: Hag ynwedh dha ober y'n treylyans an bibel . Pyth yw an kaletterow gans an treylyansow a'n  par na ?
english: And your work in Bible translation too. What are the difficulties with translations like that ?

cornish: Pyth yw an pyth ?
english: What's the what ?

cornish: Kalletter.
english: Problem.

cornish: Lies kaletter awos bos an, ny wonn vy , ny wonn vy travydh yn kever an yethow koth, Ebbrow ha  Greka,Greka martesen , mes yma Keith Said orth ow, ow weres yn henna hag my a wrug y dreylya  gwella gallav ha hi a wra ewna an.. ow skrifow fest yn ta. Eus kales, yw.
english: Many problems because the ... I don't know, I don't know anything about the old languages, Hebrew and Greek,  Greek perhaps, but there's Keith Said to help, to help me, and I translate it as quick as I can and she (sic) corrects the..  my writing very quickly. It's hard it is.

cornish: Wel kales yw drefenn bos emm... mater a gryjians ynwedh..yeth a gryjians...ha styr an  treylyans...
english: Well it's hard because it's emm... a matter of faith too...the language of faith..and the meaning of the translation...

cornish: Ya , ya...
english: Yes , yes...

cornish: Ytho... A yll'ta perthi kov a dus erell ow tyski yn kettermyn agesos ?
english: So... Can you remember other people teaching or learning the language at the same time as you ?

cornish: Wel ow dyskador dhym o Jori
english: Well, my own teacher was Jori

cornish: Jori Ansell
english: Jori Ansell

cornish: Jori Ansell ..ah.. pur skentyl..o ev.. yw ev y'n yeth.. ev a...ev a dhyski.. ev a dhyskas a lies nans  yw lies blydhen ha pur freth yw ev ...hag yma ev ow, ow hwithra ..to examine I don't know what to  examine is.an ombroforyon rag peub gradh hag ynwedh rag an pympes gradh.
english: Jori Ansell ..ah.. very knowledgeable he was, he is, in the language,..he a..he went to teach, he taught many years  ago and he was very fluent and it was he examining,..to examine I don't know what to examine is.the candidates for  each grade and then the fifth grade.

cornish: Henn yw gwir . Yma own dhym dhe brederi yn kever an pympes gradh
english: That's true. I'm afraid to think of the fifth grade.

cornish: Hag yma Koreen Twydell ow tyski tamm Kernewek y'n eur ma. Ha freth yw hi, ha Rosemary  Beedle a wrug dyski yn termyn..blydhenyow ma .....
english: And there's Koreen Twydell teaching a little Cornish now. And she's fluent, and Rosemary Beedle who taught in a  time, these years .....

cornish: Pyth a wra Rosemary y'n dydhyow ma ?
english: What's Rosemary doing these days ?

cornish: Wel ny wonn vy yn kever..yn hi hever y'n eur ma, yn termyn eus pass...
english: Well I don't know about, about here but in time pass...

cornish: Yn termyn eus passyes yth esa klas gensi dhe Lanust
english: In time gone by she had a class in St Just

cornish: Yth esa an klas yn Lanust .
english: It was a class inSt Just .

cornish: Studhoryon erell..
english: Other students..

cornish: Na na nyns eus.. wel..ty. Roger Garside
english: No there weren't well. You ... Roger Garside

cornish: Roger Garside ynwedh henn yw gwir...ha avel Denzil Monk a wra gul filmow , y'n dydhyow ma  ha nebes yn Kernewek ynwedh
english: Roger Garside too that's right...and like Denzil Monk who makes films now , and some in Cornish too.

cornish: Ev a wrug, ev a wrug studhya dhym rag unn vlydhen.. marnas Fin yw.
english: He did, he studied with me for year, only he's okay.

cornish: OK, pyth o an lettyans a dhyski?
english: OK, what obstacles were there to learning ?

cornish: Wel, pur gales yw an yeth..dhe dhyski. Ha pur gales.. nyns yw an yeth kepar ha'n Sowsnek.,hag  yma lies den a dhalleth dyski an yeth, hag ena wosa try mis, peswar mis, pymp mis ev a omdennis  ,omdennas mos bos an yeth re gales dhe dhyski An Acheson, seyth den war dek.
english: Well, the language is very hard to learn. And very hard, the language isn't like English... and many who start to learn  the language, and then after, three months, four months five months they drop out because it's become so hard to learn  the language, a reason...seven out of ten people..

cornish: Yma problems gans an grammar
english: There are problems with the a grammar

cornish: A dhe wir an dreheyyans nyns yw kepar ha henna Sowsnek po Frynkek po Almaynek,
english: Ah, truly, the construction isn't like that in English or French or German.

cornish: Wel, rag ensampel an treylyansow yw kales dhe witha yn dha brys. O an yeth y'th skol po chi ?
english: Well, for example the mutations are hard to keep in your mind. Was there any language in your school or at  home.?

cornish: Na,na
english: No, no

cornish: Pyth yw dha dybyans yn kever dyski an yeth yn skolyow ?
english: What do you think about teaching the language in schools ?

cornish: Henn yw pur dha, tybyans pur dha. Res yw'n dyski dhe'n fleghes hag i a wra hi tyski yn skol hag  yn ta deldybav.
english: That's a very good idea . It must be taught to the children and they will learn it well at school I believe.

cornish: Pyth a brederydh yn kever tybyans Akademi rag an yeth ?
english: What do you think about the idea of an Academy for the language ?

cornish: Dhe wir ya, henn yw tybyans da.
english: Really that's a very good idea.

cornish: A wruss'ta mos dh 'Yeth an werin' po neppyth a' par na?
english: Do you go to a Yeth an werin or something like that ?

cornish: Ya, pub mis oll, Wel res yw dhymm mos dhe'n yeth an werin rag goslowes orth an yeth kewsys,  nyns ov vy pur freth my a wra...my a wra ankevi lies ger, lies lavarow,
english: Yes, every month l, Well I have to go to the yeth an werin to hear the spoken language , I'm not very fluent, I do, I  forget many words, many phrases,

cornish: Henn yw attes y wul. Pyth a brederydh y'ga hever an yeth an werins ?
english: That's easy to do .What do you think about them yeth and werins ?

cornish: Umm, ny wonn vy. Wel tra dha yw an yeth an werin mes martesen an dus a dheu yw freth yn ta ,  kales yw dh'aga ombrofya dhe dhallethoryon heb konvedhes a pyth a leveris ena .
english: Umm, I don't know . Well the yeth an werin is a good thing but perhaps the people who come are very fluent, it's  hard to invite begins who won't understand what's said there .

cornish: Mes, henn yw gwir, del grysav, mes an den yowynk na, Sean,.... py lies yeth an werin re  attendyas Sean ? Martesen tri po peswar mes freth yw ev pub nos.Pyth yw dha dybyans yn kever an  yeth yn termyn a dheu ?
english: But, that's true , I believe, but that young man there, Sean... how many yeth an werins has Sean attended ?  Maybe three or four but he's fluent every night. What are your ideas for the language in the future ?

cornish: Wel del dybav hi a wra mos yn rag,mos yn rag yn skolyow, mars eus dyskadoryon lowr dh'y  dhyski. Hag yn Truru hag yn sitaow, sitaow, wel Truro mars eus sign, sinyow yn Kernewek henna via  tybyans da. Henwyn, henwyn fordhow hag arwoedhow erell yn Kernewek, y tri dhe'n werin bos an  yeth yn fyw
english: Well the way I think it will advance , go forward in schools, if there are teachers enough to teach it. And in Truro,  and in the cities, well Truro if there are signs, signs in Cornish that would be a good idea. Names, street names and  other signs in Cornish it will show the people that the language is a live one.

cornish: Wel, meur ras , my a wrug gorfennys lemmyn an govynnadow mes martesen ty a vynn leverel  neppyth y'n yeth arall
english: Well, thanks ,I've finished the questions now but perhaps you want to say something in the other language.

cornish: Well maybe. Umm, no I've been very happy to have been connected with Cornish. I still am happy  to be connected with the language. I've found it a fascinating language myself and I'm not very  competent at speaking it myself but then I don't have a lot of practice, so I think if, the more you can  get together and talk in a language, the better, but I , my strength lies more in writing it and explaining  it rather than actually speaking it.
english: Well maybe. Umm, no I've been very happy to have been connected with Cornish. I still am happy to be connected  with the language. I've found it a fascinating language myself and I'm not very competent at speaking it myself but then  I don't have a lot of practice, so I think if, the more you can get together and talk in a language, the better, but I , my  strength lies more in writing it and explaining it rather than actually speaking it.

cornish: henn yw oll
english: henn yw oll

cornish: FINE
english: FINE
